newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - MAY 15.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - MAY 15.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:

--Olympic Airways, Greece's national carrier, has had its wings clipped by the report of its structure by consultants Mckinsey and Co. which has proved what many believe about OA's anarchic management. The report stresses high wage bills, high absenteeism and overtime and guidelines which do nothing for productivity. Under the present conditions and structure, the report says, OA cannot survive more than three years. Mckinsey and Co. will request an extension of their contract to develop sub-programmes-studies for each sector or activity and to develop a management information system.
--The general price index yesterday inched towards an all-time record, closing at 1,643.69 points, up 2.03 percent.

--Prime Minister Costas Simitis yesterday urged unions and employers to "abandon their insistence on sacrificing the future on the altar of today" in his opening address to both for dialogue on changes to the job market.
--A bill submitted to Parliament opens the way for speedier procedures in mergers of banks, particularly the pending merger of the state-run Housing and Mortgage banks.

--The Athens bourse was bullish for the 12th consecutive day yesterday with industrials receiving most attention, due, brokers said, to the fall in interest rates and the search for alternate investment options.

--Simitis warned of harsh consequences being the only alternative for Greece achieving economic and monetary union if there was no progress in social dialogue. These would include a devaluation of the drachma and increased inflation and foreign lending, he said.

--Latsis Group bank Eurobank has returned profits of 4.7 billion drachmas (up 22.6 percent)in 1996 and sister bank Interbank an increase in profits of 69 percent. The combined assets of the two makes the Group's banks the third-largest private banks.
--Today is the deadline for the submission of statements by businesses on their real estate hholdings.
--The volume of retail sales saw a significant increase of 3.6 percent in January 1997.
--Shipowner Vassillis Konstantakopoulos is preparing a 40 billion drachma investment in a hotel-conference centre complex in the prefecture of Messinia.

--National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou will get his first idea of the conclusions of an International Monetary Fund committee's evaluation of the Greek economy today when he meets with the delegation's members. Sources say the IMF is less optimistic about the course of fiscal developments and urge structural reforms, privatisations, and a drastic cutback in public spending.
--A bill submitted to Parliament yesterday is designed to lower operating costs for Greek ships, increase competitiveness, and keep vessels at the Greek registry.
